title: Arlington County Open Data - The dogs of Arlington
contents:
Contents
Packages
API Calls
Transformation
Visualization
Attribution

Arlington County offers a wealth of data for free through their Open Data Portal. What better way to learn more about the area that I live than through local data analysis. This post will cover dog permit registration within the county.
Packages


xfun::pkg_attach(c("tidyverse", "httr", "jsonlite", "ggsci",
                   "ggthemr", "cowplot", "here",
                   "lubridate", "glue", "scales",
                   "janitor", "skimr", "tigris"))



API Calls
I’ll start by creating a function that creates an API call.


query_doggos <- function(skip, top) {
  GET(url = "https://datahub-v2.arlingtonva.us/api/Tax/CurrentDogLicense",
      query = list('$skip' = skip,
                   '$top' = top)) %>% 
    content(as = "text") %>% 
    fromJSON() 
}

query_doggos(0, 5) %>% 
  glimpse()


Rows: 5
Columns: 8
$ currentDogLicenseKey <int> 1, 4, 5, 6, 7
$ ownerAddressText     <chr> "10 PLEASANT AVE PORTLAND ME 04103-321…
$ paymentDate          <chr> "2020-01-06T00:00:00.000Z", "2019-09-1…
$ licenseTermCode      <chr> "LIFETIME", "LIFETIME", "LIFETIME", "3…
$ validThroughDate     <chr> "2022-05-19T00:00:00.000Z", "2022-05-0…
$ dogTagNbr            <chr> "003763L", "001143L", "001142L", "2107…
$ dogSexCode           <chr> "MALE", "MALE", "FEMALE", "MALE", "MAL…
$ spayedNeuteredInd    <chr> "YES", "YES", "YES", "YES", "NO"

The functions works but the data types for the columns will need to be updated. I’ll iterate over chunks of the data instead of querying everything at once. I’m choosing to use the purr map() function for this part of the process.


dog_permit_data <- xfun::cache_rds({
  map2_df(.x = seq(0, 10000, 100), .y = 100,
          ~query_doggos(.x, .y))
})



Transformation
Great. I’ve got all of the data. Let’s examine it again with the glimpse() function see what we ended up with.


dog_permit_data %>%
  glimpse(width = 50)


Rows: 7,155
Columns: 8
$ currentDogLicenseKey <int> 1, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, …
$ ownerAddressText     <chr> "10 PLEASANT AVE P…
$ paymentDate          <chr> "2020-01-06T00:00:…
$ licenseTermCode      <chr> "LIFETIME", "LIFET…
$ validThroughDate     <chr> "2022-05-19T00:00:…
$ dogTagNbr            <chr> "003763L", "001143…
$ dogSexCode           <chr> "MALE", "MALE", "F…
$ spayedNeuteredInd    <chr> "YES", "YES", "YES…

It looks like we have 7155 rows. I’m assuming the paymentDate column refers to when the dog permit registration was submitted. There isn’t anything super interesting about the dogs other than the genders and their spayed/neutered status at registration. The ownerAddressText column also contains zip code information that can be extracted using regular expressions. Before I can start summarizing or visualizing anything I need to perform some data cleansing/transformations.


dog_permit_clean <- dog_permit_data %>%
  clean_names() %>%
  rename(owner_address = owner_address_text, license_term = license_term_code,
         dog_gender = dog_sex_code, sn_ind = spayed_neutered_ind) %>%
  select(owner_address, payment_date, license_term, dog_gender,
         sn_ind)

dog_permit_clean <- dog_permit_clean %>%
  mutate(reg_date = parse_date_time(payment_date, orders = "%Y-%m-%d%H:%M:%S"),
         across(.cols = reg_date, 
                .fns = list(y = year, m = month, wd = weekdays), 
                .names = "reg_{fn}"),
         reg_ym = glue("{reg_y}{str_pad(reg_m, 2, 'left', '0')}"),
         curr_ym = glue("{year(Sys.Date())}{str_pad(month((Sys.Date())), 2, 'left', '0')}"),
         owner_zip = as.factor(str_extract(owner_address,
                                           "(?<=VA\\s)\\d{5}")),
         sn_ind = if_else(sn_ind == "YES", TRUE, FALSE)) %>%
  filter(str_detect(owner_address, "ARLINGTON")) %>% 
  na.omit()



Visualization
There are a lot of cool visualization that can be created from this new tidied data frame. I’ll start by graphing the frequency of dog registrations by month for each year faceted by gender.


ggthemr(palette = "solarized",
        layout = "plain",
        text_size = 15,
        spacing = 2)

dog_permit_clean %>%
  filter(reg_ym != curr_ym) %>%
  count(reg_m, reg_y) %>%
  filter(reg_y >= 2017) %>%
  mutate(reg_y = factor(reg_y,
                           levels = seq(max(dog_permit_clean$reg_y),
                                        min(dog_permit_clean$reg_y)))) %>%
  ggplot(aes(reg_m, n,
             col = reg_y)) +
  geom_line(size = 1.1) +
  geom_point(size = 3L, col = ggthemr:::get_themr()$palette$background) +
  geom_point(size = 1.9) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = breaks_width(1)) +
  labs(x = "Month", y = "n", col = "Year",
       title = "Arlington County Dog Permit Registrations",
       caption = glue("Arlington County Data API was used \\
                      for this purpose, but it is not endorsed \\
                      or certified by Arlington County.")) +
  theme(text = element_text(family = "Courier"),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 15),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.45, size = 7)) +
  scale_colour_ggthemr_d()




Arlington County didn’t start supplying registration data until 2017 so I filtered out all of the data before then. I also removed any data for the current month. I chose to overlay each year to get a better sense of how 2020 registrations compare to prior years. It looks as though the highest amount of monthly registrations were made in June of 2020. This spike could be attributed to a lag in reporting due to Covid. Or the spike could be a genuine representation of Arlingtonians’ increased desire to be dog owners during the pandemic. I’m leaning towards the latter given that the amount of registrations from January to May are still above previous years.
Next I’d like to know where the dog are registered.


arlington_sf <- xfun::cache_rds({
  tigris::zctas(starts_with = c("222"),
                          state = "virginia", cb = TRUE) %>%
    rename(zip_code = ZCTA5CE10)
})

ggthemr(palette = "solarized",
        text_size = 15,
        spacing = 0.5)

arlington_sf %>%
  left_join(dog_permit_clean %>%
              filter(reg_ym != curr_ym) %>%
              count(owner_zip),
            by = c("zip_code" = "owner_zip")) %>%
  ggplot() + geom_sf(aes(fill = n)) +
  geom_sf_label(aes(label = zip_code)) +
  theme(text = element_text(family = "Courier"),
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, size = 15),
        axis.title = element_blank(),
        axis.text = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_blank(),
        plot.caption = element_text(hjust = 0.35, size = 7)) +
  scale_fill_gradient(low = "#86C0EA", high = swatch()[1]) +
  labs(title = "Dog Permit Registrations by Zip",
       fill = "",
       caption = glue("Arlington County Data API was used \\
                      for this purpose, but it is not endorsed \\
                      or certified by Arlington County."))




This map shows me the total number of registrations per zip code.
Attribution
Arlington County Data API was used for this purpose, but it is not endorsed or certified by Arlington County.

title: Apple Health Data - Workout Activity
description: Analyzing my run recent run activity.
contents:
Packages


xfun::pkg_attach('tidyverse', 'httr', 'xml2', 'lubridate', 
                 'janitor', 'ggthemr', 'scales', 'ggsci')

ggthemr("solarized")



XML to RDS
The XML file format is great for storing data, but I will want to extract and transform the information that I want into separate data frames. This can be accomplished easily by creating a function that extracts all nodes that contain a given attribute.


xml_to_rds <- function(xml_file, attr_select) {
  
  xml2::xml_find_all(xml_file, 
                     paste0("//", attr_select)) %>% 
    purrr::map(~xml2::xml_attrs(.x)) %>%
    purrr::map_df(~as.list(.x)) %>% 
    saveRDS(file = paste0(attr_select, ".RDS"))
  
}



The top of the export.xml file contains some documentation on what elements are present within the file. I’ll focus primarily on the Workout nodes for this post.


xml_to_rds(apple_health_export, "Workout")



Data Cleansing
Great. So now I have data frame that contains all of my workout data. Before I can begin any type of analysis, I’ll need to perform a couple cleaning operations. I’ll start by cleaning up the column names.


names(workouts)


 [1] "workoutActivityType"   "duration"             
 [3] "durationUnit"          "totalDistance"        
 [5] "totalDistanceUnit"     "totalEnergyBurned"    
 [7] "totalEnergyBurnedUnit" "sourceName"           
 [9] "sourceVersion"         "creationDate"         
[11] "startDate"             "endDate"              
[13] "device"               

workouts <- workouts %>% 
  clean_names()

names(workouts)


 [1] "workout_activity_type"    "duration"                
 [3] "duration_unit"            "total_distance"          
 [5] "total_distance_unit"      "total_energy_burned"     
 [7] "total_energy_burned_unit" "source_name"             
 [9] "source_version"           "creation_date"           
[11] "start_date"               "end_date"                
[13] "device"                  

Next I want to make sure that each variable has the correct data type. I can inspect the current column type with glimpse().


workouts %>% 
  select(-device) %>% 
  glimpse()


Rows: 114
Columns: 12
$ workout_activity_type    <chr> "HKWorkoutActivityTypeRunning", "H…
$ duration                 <chr> "30.19625363349915", "31.566619833…
$ duration_unit            <chr> "min", "min", "min", "min", "min",…
$ total_distance           <chr> "3.02360045806866", "3.07297265789…
$ total_distance_unit      <chr> "mi", "mi", "mi", "mi", "mi", "mi"…
$ total_energy_burned      <chr> "296.1570000000004", "294.944", "3…
$ total_energy_burned_unit <chr> "Cal", "Cal", "Cal", "Cal", "Cal",…
$ source_name              <chr> "Matthew’s Apple Watch", "Matthew’…
$ source_version           <chr> "3.1", "3.2.2", "3.2.2", "3.2.2", …
$ creation_date            <chr> "2017-05-15 19:13:44 -0500", "2017…
$ start_date               <chr> "2017-05-15 18:43:28 -0500", "2017…
$ end_date                 <chr> "2017-05-15 19:13:40 -0500", "2017…

It looks as though all of the variables are currently categorized as characters. I can fix this using a combination of the mutate() and across() functions. I’m also adjusting the time to match my current timezone. Most of the data that I will be analyzing was captured during 2020, so I’m pretty sure I didn’t travel to any other timezones.


workouts <- workouts %>% 
  select(-device) %>% 
  mutate(across(.cols = contains("date"),
                .fns = ~as_datetime(.x) - seconds(18000)),
         across(.cols = c(duration, total_distance, 
                          total_energy_burned),
                .fns = ~as.double(.x)))

workouts %>% 
  glimpse()


Rows: 114
Columns: 12
$ workout_activity_type    <chr> "HKWorkoutActivityTypeRunning", "H…
$ duration                 <dbl> 30.19625, 31.56662, 38.16131, 30.2…
$ duration_unit            <chr> "min", "min", "min", "min", "min",…
$ total_distance           <dbl> 3.023600, 3.072973, 3.137175, 3.09…
$ total_distance_unit      <chr> "mi", "mi", "mi", "mi", "mi", "mi"…
$ total_energy_burned      <dbl> 296.1570, 294.9440, 347.7160, 287.…
$ total_energy_burned_unit <chr> "Cal", "Cal", "Cal", "Cal", "Cal",…
$ source_name              <chr> "Matthew’s Apple Watch", "Matthew’…
$ source_version           <chr> "3.1", "3.2.2", "3.2.2", "3.2.2", …
$ creation_date            <dttm> 2017-05-15 19:13:44, 2017-05-29 0…
$ start_date               <dttm> 2017-05-15 18:43:28, 2017-05-29 0…
$ end_date                 <dttm> 2017-05-15 19:13:40, 2017-05-29 0…

Analysis and Visualization
On to the fun stuff. With my cleaned and formatted data, I can finally start to answer some questions. Let’s determine what workout activity I’ve done the most, on which days, and at what times.


workouts %>% 
  count(workout_activity_type)


# A tibble: 2 x 2
  workout_activity_type            n
  <chr>                        <int>
1 HKWorkoutActivityTypeRunning   100
2 HKWorkoutActivityTypeWalking    14

workouts <- workouts %>% 
  filter(workout_activity_type == "HKWorkoutActivityTypeRunning") %>% 
  mutate(workout_day = weekdays(start_date),
         workout_day = factor(workout_day, 
                              levels = c("Monday", "Tuesday",
                                         "Wednesday", "Thursday",
                                         "Friday", "Saturday",
                                         "Sunday")),
         workout_hour = hour(start_date))

workouts %>% 
  ggplot(aes(workout_day)) + geom_bar() +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = breaks_width(5)) +
  labs(x = "Weekday", y = "Count")



workouts %>% 
  ggplot(aes(workout_hour)) + geom_bar() +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = breaks_width(2)) +
  labs(x = "Hour", y = "Count")




So far I have 100 runs recorded. I’ve tried to stick to a running schedule of Monday, Wednesday, Friday, and Sunday. I also tend to go on most of my runs before 12:00 PM.
I’ve tried to use running as a good way to stay active during the pandemic and haven’t really focused on increasing my performance. It would still be interesting to see if I have either gotten faster or increased the distance that I’m running.


workouts %>% 
  filter(workout_activity_type == "HKWorkoutActivityTypeRunning") %>% 
  mutate(min_per_mile = duration(duration / total_distance, "minute"),
         creation_date = date(creation_date)) %>% 
  filter(creation_date > "2020-01-01", 
         total_distance >= 1.5) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(creation_date, 
             min_per_mile, 
             col = total_distance)) + 
  scale_color_gradient(low = "blue", high = "red", 
                       breaks = seq(1.5, 4, 0.5)) +
  geom_point(size = 3.5, alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_y_time(labels = time_format("%M:%S"),
               breaks = breaks_width(30)) +
  scale_x_date(breaks = breaks_width("month"), 
               date_labels = "%b %Y") +
  labs(x = "Date", y = "Avg. Minutes / Mile",
       col = "Miles") +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE, col = "black",
              linetype = 2)




The plot above displays my average minutes per mile for each run. I’ve also mapped my distance to a gradient for each run. The darker blue indicates that a run was closer to 2 miles while the red indicates a distance of 3 miles or more. Most of the dots appear to be redder in hue. I currently have an average distance across all of my runs of 2.98 miles. My distance may have stayed fairly constant since I started, but it looks like I’m getting faster. Now might be a good time for me to start to lengthen my runs.

title: Exporting data to multiple Excel tabs or files
description: Exporting multiple data frames to separte Excel tabs or files with R.
contents:
Goals
Being able to export and share your work is a key step in the data analysis process. In this post I’ll walk through the process of performing some group level summary statistics and exporting those grouped data frames to separate tabs within an Excel document and separate Excel workbooks.
Packages
The key package for this demonstration will be writexl. It allows you to read/create Excel files without having to install other Java or Perl dependencies.


xfun::pkg_attach("dplyr", "readr", "tidyr", 
                 "purrr", "writexl", "lubridate")



Data Import and Summarization
I’ll be using a data set that contains performance statistics on Formula 1 drivers.


f1_summary <- read_rds("large_data/f1_master_table.rds") %>% 
  # Removes special characters from driver names
  mutate_at(c("forename", "surname"), 
            ~iconv(x = ., from = "UTF-8", 
                   to = "ASCII", "")) %>%
  filter(race_year >= 2000) %>%
  mutate(podium = if_else(fl_position <= 3, 
                          TRUE, FALSE)) %>%
  group_by(driverId, race_year, forename, surname) %>%
  summarize(total_races = n(),
            fasest_lap = min(fastestLapTime, na.rm = TRUE),
            total_podiums = sum(podium, na.rm = TRUE),
            total_points = sum(points, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  ungroup()

head(f1_summary)


# A tibble: 6 x 8
  driverId race_year forename surname total_races fasest_lap
     <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>    <chr>         <int> <drtn>    
1        1      2007 Lewis    Hamilt…          17 72.506 se…
2        1      2008 Lewis    Hamilt…          18 74.159 se…
3        1      2009 Lewis    Hamilt…          17 74.345 se…
4        1      2010 Lewis    Hamilt…          19 73.851 se…
5        1      2011 Lewis    Hamilt…          19 77.209 se…
6        1      2012 Lewis    Hamilt…          20 77.020 se…
# … with 2 more variables: total_podiums <int>, total_points <dbl>

Splitting and Exporting the Data to Separate Tabs
Now that the table is in the desired format I can split it based upon the race_year variable using the group_split function. This allows me to separate the data and keep the grouping variable in the split tables. In order for the sheet naming to work correctly I also need to name the list of data frames that I have created. This is done by using the set_names function. I’m choosing to use the race years to create the names for the list. The final step is to pipe the named list of data frames into the write_xlsx function where it it used to create the Excel workbook with it’s named tabs.


f1_summary %>%
  group_split(race_year) %>%
  set_names(map_chr(.x = .,
                    .f = ~ .$race_year %>%
                      unique() %>%
                      as.character())) %>%
  write_xlsx(path = "annual_f1_data.xlsx")




Exporting to Multiple Excel Files
A similar process is used to export the data frames into separate Excel files. This time I will be nesting the data and mapping over the data frames to create each file. The nest function allows me to use the grouping variable, in this case race_year, to name each Excel file.


f1_summary %>%
  mutate(ry = race_year) %>%
  nest(data = -race_year) %>% 
  arrange(race_year) %>%
  walk2(.x = .$data, .y = .$race_year,
      .f = ~write_xlsx(x = .x,
                   path = paste0("f1_data_", .y, ".xlsx")))

title: Animating plots in R
description: Using Plotly to animate plots in R.
contents:
Contents
Goals
Packages
Data Import
Data Transformation
Static plot
Creating the animated plot!!!

Goals
Animated visualization can be great for communicating changes over time that might be harder to interpret from static plots. My goal is to calculate the per year podium counts for each of the top ten constructors. I then want to create a plot in Plotly that will allow me animate the change in podiums over time.
Packages
First we need to the packages need for this analysis.


library(tidyverse)
library(lubridate)
library(scales)
library(plotly)
library(ggsci)
library(here)



Data Import
The data used for this analysis can be found at the following link. 
Formula One Data
Data Transformation
Before I can create the animated plot I need to transform the data into a format that will be easier to work with.


f1_data %>%
  #Groups by constructor name
  group_by(c_name) %>%
  #Calculates the total podiums by constructor
  summarize(total_p = sum(podium)) %>%
  #Filters olnly for the top 10 constructors 
  #by total podiums
  top_n(10, total_p) %>%
  #Pulls the constructor name column out as a vector
  pull(c_name) -> top_10_const



With the top ten constructors identified, I can compute the additional value needed for the animated plot: the cumulative podium wins per year.


f1_data %>%
  #Filters by the top constructors identified 
  #from the previous step
  filter(c_name %in% top_10_const) %>%
  #Groups by the race year and contructor name
  group_by(race_year, c_name) %>%
  #Calculates the total podiums per year for 
  #each constructor
  summarize(annual_podium = sum(podium)) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  #Sort the data by race year to ensure that the
  #cumulative calculations work correctly
  arrange(race_year) %>%
  #Pivots the data into a wide format so that each 
  #constructor with their annual podium count is in a 
  #seperate column
  pivot_wider(names_from = c_name, 
              values_from = annual_podium) %>%
  #Replaces NA values with 0. This will ensure that the
  #cumulative podium calculation doesn't skip years where
  #there isn't data
  map_df(~if_else(is.na(.x), 0, .x)) %>%
  #Pivots the data back to the long format
  pivot_longer(cols = c(2:ncol(.)), 
               names_to = "c_name", 
               values_to = "annual_podium") %>%
  #Nest the data by constructor name
  group_by(c_name) %>%
  nest() %>%
  #Calculates the cumulative podium count for each year
  #for each consrtuctor
  mutate(cum_podiums = map(data, 
                            ~cumsum(.x$annual_podium))) %>%
  unnest(c(data, cum_podiums)) %>%
  #Drops the annual podium column
  ungroup() %>%
  select(-annual_podium) -> const_top_10

const_top_10 %>%
  head()


# A tibble: 6 x 3
  c_name  race_year cum_podiums
  <chr>       <dbl>       <dbl>
1 Ferrari      1950           3
2 Ferrari      1951          16
3 Ferrari      1952          33
4 Ferrari      1953          49
5 Ferrari      1954          63
6 Ferrari      1955          72

Static plot
For comparison I have utilized our new values to visualize the podium performance with a static plot. In order to communicate the same information I’ve chosen to facet the plots by year. Since there are so many years to facet the plot becomes noisy and difficult to interpret. Now lets see how the animated plot performs.


const_top_10 %>%
  ggplot(aes(c_name, cum_podiums, fill = c_name)) + 
  geom_col() + facet_wrap(~race_year) + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45)) +
  scale_fill_npg() + labs(x = "Top 10 Constructors",
                          y = "Total Podiums",
                          fill = "")




Creating the animated plot!!!
The animated plot is fairly easy to create. I just need to supply the race_year column to the frame parameter. This will allow anyone to use the slider to move through time and see how podiums counts have changed for each constructor. It’s also way easier to compare the performance of each constructor and identify trends.


plot_ly(const_top_10,
        x = ~c_name,
        y = ~cum_podiums,
        color = ~c_name,
        colors = my_pal,
        type = "bar",
        frame = ~race_year) %>% 
  layout(yaxis = list(title = "Total Podiums"),
         xaxis = list(title = "Top 10 Constructors")) %>%
  animation_slider(currentvalue = list(prefix = "Year "))



{"x":{"visdat":{"b8c617b694e7":["function () ","plotlyVisDat"]},"cur_data":"b8c617b694e7","attrs":{"b8c617b694e7":{"x":{},"y":{},"color":{},"frame":{},"colors":["#E64B35FF","#4DBBD5FF","#00A087FF","#3C5488FF","#F39B7FFF","#8491B4FF","#91D1C2FF"],"alpha_stroke":1,"sizes":[10,100],"spans":[1,20],"type":"bar"}},"layout":{"margin":{"b":40,"l":60,"t":25,"r":10},"yaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"title":"Total Podiums","range":[-36.9,774.9]},"xaxis":{"domain":[0,1],"automargin":true,"title":"Top 10 Constructors","type":"category","categoryorder":"array","categoryarray":["Benetton","Brabham","Ferrari","McLaren","Mercedes","Red Bull","Renault","Team
